Lesson 7: Email Marketing

Image by Brett Jordan under Unsplash

  • What is the goal of email marketing?
    • Communicate with families using a common tool (not everyone uses social media)
    • Can be more strategic and intentional rather than short, rapid-fire social media posts
    • Can feel more personal for private communications
    • Email is more transactional (e.g., receiving offers) than just social (e.g., chatting with friends)
    • Don’t think email vs. social media. Instead, they can be used together to maximize your message
  • What do you communicate with email?
    • Send newsletters, reminders, links, etc.
    • Send special offers to prospective families (e.g., waive the registration fee for a specific period of time if they enroll)
    • Invitations to events (e.g., end-of-year celebration, art show, ice cream social, etc.)
    • Be intentional about what you are sending. Have a goal in mind for the communication. Be short and to the point.
    • Make sure that emails that are sent work with all devices
  • How do you know it’s effective?
    • Email providers such as Gmail offer built-in tools that can analyze the effectiveness of your email campaigns. There are also tools that can be linked to your email account to track effectiveness. An internet search for “email analytics tools” will result in several to choose from.
    • A few metrics to consider tracking include:
      • Open Rate: number of emails that people opened
      • Click-through Rate: amount of emails where people clicked on one or more of the links that were included
      • Conversion Rate: the amount of emails where people clicked through and acted on the message inside (e.g., completed an inquiry form)
      • You can also track the effectiveness by asking people how they heard about a promotion (e.g., waiving a registration fee). Understanding how many families responded/enrolled after a promotion can provide insight into its effectiveness and confirm if it was a good use of time and resources.
